author: Rafael Sanchez-Cruz
title: Family thanks heroes who saved mom and son from Beltway crash | wusa9.com
text: A video captured by a witness shows when several people stepped in to pull Scheracon Roberts Brown and her son Aarihimis Brown, 5, from the debris that was on fire. On April 8, officers with the Prince George's County Fire Department responded just before 11 a.m. to the outer loop of I-495 SB near Maryland Route 4 for reports o a crash. Once there, they found [fire showing from an overturned dump truck](/article/traffic/6-people-taken-to-hospital-after-multi-vehicle-crash-on-i-495/65-1c2a42a3-9b7a-4fab-8967-6a709ca0d321). Roberts Brown's younger sister, Elaina Nesbitt, said her nephew was accompanying his mother. "She didn't have anyone to watch the baby," Elaina Nesbitt said. "So she was like, well we still have to go to work. So she put the baby in the seat thinking it was a regular work day." The initial investigation shows that the dump truck was traveling north on I-495 when it blew a tire. The dump truck then traveled into the southbound lanes where it overturned and caught fire. At the same time, an SUV traveling south on I-495 tried to avoid the dump truck and overturned. An adult and child travelling in the SUV were also injured, according to Maryland State Police. Emanuel Nesbitt says his daughter took after him and became a truck driver. "One of those unfortunate things that happen, but we just still say thank you," Emanuel Nesbitt said. "Thank you for saving her life, Jesus Christ. Thank you all for being here and caring for her." The family said both mother and son are alert and communicating through gestures after going through several surgeries. Emanuel Nesbit told reporters that doctors have given them a five to eight month recovery timeframe, but he fears healing the emotional scars will take longer. After spending days sedated, Roberts Brown's mother, says her daughter only wanted to know one thing when she awoke. "Where is my son? She had gotten him out of the seat and was pushing him out of the truck for him to get out of the flames," Brenda Roberts Nesbitt said. [The boy's father](/article/news/community/father-thanks-people-saved-5-year-old-fiery-wreck/65-89032623-c200-4d1d-bc40-564a1d300687), Actwood Brown, says abdominal issues have complicated his son's recovery. "Seeing his mom in the condition that she was in, and her screaming, he's got a long road as well, physically and mentally," Brown said. The family says they have seen the video of the rescue. "It's a life altering situation, that someone had the courage and the heart to say, I'm going to help them," Elaina Nesbitt said. In the video , Bishop John Adonteng Boateng is seen carrying and comforting the 5-year-old boy. The family was able to thank the bishop in person outside of the Johns Hopkins Hospital where Aarihimis is still hospitalized. "I shouldn't be called a hero in these circumstances," Adonteng Boateng said as he carried a gift and card for the boy. "There were other men and women also. A man named Anthony, a truck driver, and another guy and a lady who is a nurse. And a whole lot of people that came in strong who were ready to die just to save the woman and child." Roberts Brown said their family's heartfelt thanks go out to all who stepped in. "Thank you for everything you've done to assist my family so that they can live," she said. The family says the boy has a surgery scheduled for April 19. Do you have a news tip on this story or any other story? We want to hear from you. Tell us about it by emailing [newstips@wusa9.com](mailto:newstips@wusa9.com). MORE WAYS TO GET WUSA9 DOWNLOAD THE WUSA9 APP Apple App Store: WUSA9 News on Apple Google Play Store: WUSA9 News on Android HOW TO ADD THE FREE WUSA9+ APP TO YOUR STREAMING DEVICE ROKU: add the channel from the ROKU store or by searching for WUSA9. For both Apple TV and Fire TV, search for "WUSA9" to find the free app to add to your account. Another option for Fire TV is to have the app delivered directly to your Fire TV through Amazon. SIGN UP TO RECEIVE WUSA9 NEWSLETTER Subscribe to our [daily WUSA9 Newsletter](/email) for top stories from WUSA9 curated daily just for you. Get content and information right now for canâ€™t-miss stories, Commanders content, weather, and more delivered right to your inbox.

author: PA News Agency
title: Off-road drivers were swept away by river, says man who tried to save them | The Argus
text:
A man who tried to save three men trapped in a submerged 4Ã—4 vehicle said they were â€œswept awayâ€ as they attempted to cross a river.
Emergency services including police, ambulance and a helicopter attended a location on the River Esk near Glaisdale shortly before midday on Thursday.
A 4Ã—4 was recovered from the river by the fire service just after 3pm and three men found inside had died, North Yorkshire Police said.
Chris Ford, who lives nearby, told the PA news agency the men were part of an off-roading group when they crossed a ford on Rake Lane.
The river, swollen by heavy rain, swept them away and carried them around 400 yards downstream, he said.
Emergency services have been dealing with a serious incident on Thursday (28 December) involving a 4Ã—4 vehicle in the River Esk near Glaisdale on the North York Moors ðŸš¨
Three men sadly died at the scene.
More information is available here â¬‡ï¸ https://t.co/KgxPhHATO4 pic.twitter.com/AvDT3TiqCk
â€” North Yorkshire Police (@NYorksPolice) December 28, 2023
It came as Storm Gerrit caused flooding and travel chaos across the country throughout Wednesday and Thursday.
Mr Ford, a firewood salesman, was called to the scene to help recover the vehicle with his tractor and found it fully submerged beneath the water, he said.
He and two others used tractors to pull the 4Ã—4 on to the riverbank, he said.
Police said another man, who attempted to help those trapped in the car, was pulled from the river and needed medical treatment.
Mr Ford told PA: â€œThere was a ford they were going over and they were swept down 400 yards.
â€œThey were part of an off-road club.
â€œI went down with my tractor. There was a couple of vehicles â€“ one parked up.
â€œYou couldnâ€™t see the (other) vehicle. It was 3ft beneath the water.
â€œI helped get it out on to the riverbank with three other tractors.â€
Two other locals, Rosie and Andrew Dale, said they were with Mr Ford when he got the call to help.
They said they saw several 4Ã—4 vehicles pass their home in the direction of the ford shortly before the incident.
Mrs Dale said â€œnobody localâ€ would attempt to cross the ford in the current conditions.
The area is popular with 4Ã—4 drivers, she said, adding: â€œIn the summer you get 10 of them at a time.â€
A spokesperson for North Yorkshire Police said: â€œLocalised conditions across our area are making driving hazardous.
â€œRoads are particularly badly affected around the River Esk, to the north of the county, as we have seen with the tragic incident near Glaisdale.
â€œThere was another incident at nearby Houlsyke at 12.49pm when a car got stuck in flood water and another at Kirby Wiske in Hambleton at 2.35pm.
â€œThankfully, the occupants of both vehicles were brought to safety.
â€œThe key advice is to consider whether your journey is necessary.
â€œPlease avoid driving through any kind of standing or moving flood water if you possibly can.â€
Witnesses to the incident at Glaisdale are urged to call North Yorkshire Police on 101, option 4, quoting reference NYP-28122023-0146.

author: Nathaniel Hunter
title: These Polish nuns risked their lives resisting the Nazis - U.S. Catholic
text: Greater love has no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends (John 15:13). On Palm Sunday in 1942, a traumatized Jewish child knocked on the convent door of the Sisters of St. Joseph in the small Polish village of Trzesowka. The shabbily dressed girl insisted she was Polish and Roman Catholic and said her parents had just been killed by the Germans. The nuns were familiar with all the local children and suspected she might be one of the Jewish refugees hiding in the forests. Their intuition was correct. They later learned that her mother had died of suicide, and her father was missing. That was the year the Nazis began using gas chambers for the mass murder of Jewish people. The punishment for sheltering a Jewish person was executionâ€”of the rescuer and anyone living with them. In Poland at that time, thousands of nuns and priests, along with professors and politicians, were also targeted for execution and imprisonment. Despite knowing these risks, the sisters didnâ€™t hesitate to bring Rachela into the convent. Courage often shines most brightly in the darkest of times. The Sisters of St. Joseph understood that God sometimes asks us to show strength and bravery in helping to defend the vulnerable. Located in Polandâ€™s most impoverished area, Trzesowka was a world apart from the more progressive and cosmopolitan cities of Warsaw and Krakow. The convent, which was established in 1925, faced the same poverty as the villagers. In the years before World War II, the convent sisters were involved in many charitable activities, such as conducting school, and organizing sewing classes and camps for children. They also cared for the ill in the nearby villages and were consulted on all sorts of practical matters. The sistersâ€™ medical services proved invaluable for the villagers as there were no local doctors or clinics. Most sisters were trained as nurses and gained experience in hospitals before the war. They were also known for their knowledge of herbal medicines, often the only locally available remedy. The villagesâ€™ houses were far away from each other in the wilderness, so the sisters were forced to travel long distances to treat the ill. During her five years of caring for the sick in Trzesowka, one sister recalled that none of her patients died, even though she performed some dangerous procedures. One night, she was called to treat a seriously ill boy suspected of having encephalitis. A trip to the doctor was impossible because of the long distance. She used her treatments and available medications, and he was much better within a few days. He was soon helping his parents in the fields. In addition to their charitable endeavors, the sisters supported their convent by farming their own lands, an arduous task because of the barren, sandy soil. This part of Poland had no modern services such as electricity, phones, or running water. Early each day, with a sickle in hand, the sisters made the sign of the cross and walked silently to their fieldwork â€œwhile the birds sang.â€ After three hours of work, they attended Mass. Then, they spent the hottest hours doing housework and service projects for the community. In the late afternoon, they again worked the fields by hand without any machinery. Despite their many duties, the sisters found time to grow colorful flowers in their gardens. Convent life was spartan. Each nun had her own room, or cell, equipped with a bed, a small table, and a wardrobe. A simple chapel for daily prayer was furnished with a large crucifix on the wall, two paintings, a pair of kneelers, and a stoup with holy water by the door. On September 1, 1939, the Germans invaded Poland. The occupying forces terminated most of the sistersâ€™ charitable and community efforts. The German military soon took over a massive forested area a few miles from the convent to build Camp Heidelager. This was the largest SS training camp outside of Germany and included a concentration and extermination camp. During the war, Germany began the process of â€œLebensraumâ€ to develop Poland as the breadbasket of the occupied countries. They gradually colonized Poland with Germans and used the Poles as forced and slave labor. Germanyâ€™s long-term plans included targeting the Polish people for extinction. When Polish soldiers sought shelter in the area, the sisters cared for their wounded. The nuns shared their medicine, food, and medical supplies, even making bandages from bed linen and their clothes. Desperate Jewish refugees, fleeing the Nazis, also sought help from the sisters. Since the Gestapo frequently raided and searched the convent, several sisters fled and found shelter in an empty cottage in the forested wilderness in October 1941. There, they frequently helped both Jewish refugees and partisan soldiers to hide from the Germans. But after the Germans found and shot two people who were hiding next to the house, the sisters decided to return to Trzesowka. Two days after they left, the Germans burned down the cottage. In 1943, Hitler moved his top-secret V missile research project to nearby Blizna. Because of the conventâ€™s close proximity to the launch areas, the sisters frequently heard the whistles of bullets and bombs. Then, in July 1944, the Germans abandoned Camp Heidelager. The convent then became a makeshift hospital serving many injured and those exhausted by hunger and disease from the war. The sisters walked from house to house to tend to the ill, as no one had a horse for transportation. In 1946, with the convent devastated by the Germans and then plundered by the Russians, the sisters set about reorganizing to start an orphanage. Rachela, the little girl who came to the convent door asking for assistance, was only one of the Jewish refugees who turned to the sisters. Though initially she hid the truth about her Jewish identity, eventually, she trusted the sisters enough to tell them her story. One of the nuns, Sister Roberta, raised and educated Rachela until she went to university in Krakow. Sister Robertaâ€™s and Rachelaâ€™s testimonies are among a few first-hand accounts from both a Holocaust rescuer and a survivor. Their stories illustrate the profound impact acts of kindness can have in the midst of unimaginable cruelty. Later, Poland was taken over by the Soviet Union, which confiscated most of the conventâ€™s livestock and farmlands. As time progressed, the farm ran a deficit, and the convent could no longer function as a religious order in Trzesowka. The convent closed on November 27, 1986, and the house is now under private ownership. I often reflect on the moral and ethical dilemma these nuns experienced and wonder what I would have done if I lived during WWII in Poland. Would I have sheltered a Jewish refugee, even knowing my children and grandchildren might be killed if the Germans found out? The Sisters of St. Joseph lovingly risked their lives not only serving the terrorized and impoverished villagers of Trzesowka but also assisting the partisan fighters and the Jews whom the occupying forces were targeting. Today, the sisters do not qualify for Yad Vashemâ€™s â€œRighteous Among the Nationsâ€ designation because of the lack of required testimony. However, we can say about them, in the words of Jesusâ€™ parable: â€œWell done, good and faithful servant!â€ Header image: Sister Roberta Sutkowska Convent School 1939 (Elzbeita Wilk, permission granted in writing.)

author: Mike Szvetitz FrontPageBets
title: Packers vs. Eagles Week 1 NFL player props in Brazil
text:
For the first time ever, the NFL heads to Brazil.
And this historic international event features two of the NFLâ€™s top young quarterbacks, who will square off in SÃ£o Paulo on Friday night in Week 1 action.
Thatâ€™s right, Jordan Love will lead the Green Bay Packers into Neo Quimica Arena against Jalen Hurts and the Philadelphia Eagles on Friday night, with the Eagles being a 2.5-point favorite.
Itâ€™s TGIF, NFL style, as FrontPageBets takes a look at its top player props for the Packers vs. Eagles in Brazil.
Best NFL Betting Sites For Week 1 Friday Night Player Props READ: Best NFL Betting Sites for Eagles vs. Packers People are also readingâ€¦ Nebraska volleyball loses to unranked team for first time in over 6 years Sexyy Red delivers disappointingly short, but entertaining Lincoln show Malachi Coleman headed for redshirt season, Nebraska coach Matt Rhule says Nebraska high school football rankings, Sept. 2 One Lincoln winner is holding a $280,000 Nebraska Pick 5 ticket Man killed in UTV accident north of Lincoln Tank's Country bar brings love for Huskers, country music to Lincoln Railyard Man who died after falling out of UTV in Lancaster County identified One injured in shooting in downtown Lincoln late Thursday Recalled school board member called unqualified to serve on state library board 5-stars, flips and key 2026 targets: Nebraska football set for major recruiting weekend Colorado taking throwback approach to Nebraska rivalry; Deion Sanders weighs in on Dylan Raiola That photo of people wearing 'Nebraska Walz's for Trump' shirts? They're distant cousins Nebraska to revive balloon touchdown tradition for Colorado game 'This isn't going to shake our faith': Da'Nelle and Kurt Earl fight cancer battle with love, hope Best Packers vs. Eagles Player Props for Week 1: Jalen Hurts, Jordan Love props & more The Eagles enter the 2024 season still smarting from the way they finished last year. After starting 10-1, Philadelphia lost six of its last seven, including a Wild Card playoff loss to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Not the way the 2022 NFC champs wanted to go out.
The Packers, led by Love in his first season as the starter, beat the Dallas Cowboys in the Wild Card round last year only to fall to the NFC champion San Francisco 49ers in the Divisional round.
However, it was a glimpse of things to come for the young Packers as they are favored just behind the Lions to win the NFC North this year.
Jalen Hurts props: Under 280.5 passing + rushing yards on Friday Night Football (-115 or better) Since bursting onto the scene in 2020, Hurts has led the Eagles with both his arm and his legs, racking up, including playoffs, 72 passing touchdowns and 46 rushing scores.
The dual-thread quarterback has been Phillyâ€™s go-to in short-yardage and goal-line situations, coining and perfecting the â€œTush Push.â€
But Hurts hurts defenses more in the short field than he does in wide-open spaces.
He averaged 262.1 combined yards per game in 2023, including the playoffs; and for his career, Hurts has a 232-yard-per-game passing + rushing average.
Eagles vs. Packers props: Jordan Love Under 253.5 passing yards (-115 or better) Love finished last season ranked seventh in the NFL in passing, racking up 4,159 regular-season passing yards.
Including the playoffs, the Packers quarterback averaged just over 243 passing yards per game.
He only threw for 250 or more yards in eight of his 19 games last season, including only two games with 300 or more yards through the air.
In Week 1 last year, Love threw for 245 yards in a win over the Chicago Bears. But three of his passes went for touchdowns.
Packers vs. Eagles anytime TD picks: Saquon Barkley (-105 or better) When healthy, Saquon Barkley is one of the best all-purpose backs in the NFL.
And now that heâ€™s got a new team, heading to the Eagles in the offseason from the NFC East rival New York Giants, Barkley has his health and a new offense to showcase his talents â€“ one of which is finding the end zone.
In 76 career NFL games, including playoffs, Barkley has scored 49 times â€“ 37 rushing and 12 receiving. His best season was his rookie year in 2018, when he rushed for 11 and caught four TDs.
Barkley will take a lot of the rushing load off Hurts and provide the Eagles with another red-zone option, as well as a home run threat.
Look for Barkley to find paydirt a lot this season, including Friday night in SÃ£o Paulo.
Best Packers vs. Eagles player props for Friday Night Football Week 1 Jalen Hurts props: Under 280.5 passing + rushing yards (-115 or better) Jordan Love props: Under 253.5 passing yards (-115 or better) Packers vs. Eagles anytime TD picks in Brazil: Saquon Barkley (-105 or better)

author: Diario El Dia de La Plata www.eldia.com
title: Nuevo paro universitario en colegios y facultades
text:
El gremio de docentes universitarios realizarÃ¡ hoy y maÃ±ana una nueva huelga de actividades en colegios y facultades con la finalidad de exponer la protesta al Gobierno Nacional por la ausencia de una negociaciÃ³n para la recomposiciÃ³n salarial. TambiÃ©n se reclama el aumento de las partidas de financiamiento del sistema pÃºblico de educaciÃ³n superior.
La medida de fuerza se complementarÃ¡ con la realizaciÃ³n de manifestaciones callejeras en La Plata y otros puntos del paÃ­s que son sede de universidades pÃºblicas.

â€œExigimos salarios docentes y nodocentes dignos, mÃ¡s y mejores becas, mÃ¡s presupuesto para las universidades y el tratamiento y la aprobaciÃ³n de la Ley de Financiamiento Universitarioâ€, se expresÃ³ en las Ãºltimas horas en forma pÃºblica, en un mensaje que circulÃ³ en las redes sociales con adhesiÃ³n de los gremios de docentes, nodocentes y de la federaciÃ³n estudiantil (Fulp).
Carlos Defeo, titular de Conadu, la central docente a nivel nacional que convoca al paro, indicÃ³ que tambiÃ©n se prevÃ© una movilizaciÃ³n hacia la sede de la secretarÃ­a de EducaciÃ³n de la NaciÃ³n, en la capital federal.
El gremialista sostuvo que no hay diÃ¡logo entre el Gobierno y los gremios. â€œLa Ãºltima vez que hablamos fue en octubreâ€, dijo Defeo en los Ãºltimos dÃ­as, cuando se confirmÃ³ la realizaciÃ³n del paro de 48 horas.
LE PUEDE INTERESAR
Actividades: folclore, Inti Raymi
LE PUEDE INTERESAR
QuedÃ³ un arreglo sin realizar y hay peligro para andar por la vereda
De allÃ­ para acÃ¡, los gremios de docentes y nodocentes realizaron paros en todos los meses que lleva el ciclo acadÃ©mico en las universidades nacionales.
Por otra parte, presentaron un proyecto ante el Congreso Nacional que plantea el aumento de partidas.
